block.p: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
Opera

''MARRIAGE OF FIGARO.'' The homespun but attractive qualities of the Amato Opera's productions and the intimacy of its shoe-box theater offer a useful change of perspective for operagoers used to the big houses uptown. The casts here vary: at the very least, the singers are eager and enthusiastic; sometimes the singing shows great promise. And Anthony Amato, the company's founder, conducts the performances with an evident love of the music. The closing production of the company's season is Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' performed in English. Tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2:30 p.m. Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village. Tickets: $25; $20 for the elderly and children; (212) 228-8200 (Allan Kozinn).

Classical

BARGEMUSIC. There are few better places in the city to hear chamber music than on this barge floating on the East River, with its live, intimate acoustics and its spectacular view of lower Manhattan. Good weather will only enhance the experience, and the performances are often as fine as the setting. Here, in programs of elegant simplicity coordinated by Ronald Thomas, a fine cellist, he and Edward Auer, a pianist, perform Schubert's two piano trios tonight and on Sunday, and Schumann's three piano trios tomorrow. Mark Peskanov is the violinist in the Schubert, Carmit Zori in the Schumann. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, and Sunday at 4 p.m., Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-4061. Tickets: $23; $20 for the elderly; $15 for students (James R. Oestreich).

HILDEGARD BEHRENS. The German soprano Hildegard Behrens has been an indisputably great artist. Her voice is also indisputably rough and worn these days. She is still capable of compelling work, though one never can tell what to expect. The program of songs by Liszt, Wagner, Brahms, Berg and Strauss that she is presenting tonight with the fine pianist Ken Noda at the Metropolitan Museum of Art may just bring out the best in her. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $40; (212) 570-3949 (Anthony Tommasini).

MATTHIAS GOERNE. This magnificently expressive German baritone is in town for two recitals as part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series. At the first last weekend, Mr. Goerne was in superb form. The program for his second recital is devoted to works by Schumann and Wolf. The pianist is Eric Schneider. Sunday at 2 p.m., Alice Tully Hall. (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $38. (Kozinn).

OSVALDO GOLIJOV. This Argentine composer, who studied in Israel and now lives in the United States, typically brings together the music of different cultures in his work. At the moment he is working on a setting of the ''St. Mark Passion'' on a commission from the International Bach Academy as part of the commemoration of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death. It is to have its premiere in Stuttgart in September and in Boston in February but Mr. Golijov and an ensemble that includes singers, percussionists, keyboard players and a guitarist are to give a preview of excerpts from the work as part of the Zoom: Composers Close-Up series. Tomorrow night at 9, Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan. (212) 501-3330. Tickets are offered on a ''pay what you can'' basis; the suggested price is $9 (Kozinn).

DON HULBERT. Here is a gifted flutist who delights as much in versatility as in virtuosity. When last encountered a couple of years ago, Mr. Hulbert played both Baroque and modern flutes and joined a variety of talented colleagues in a wide range of repertory. Here, in a program called ''Pictorial Music,'' he does the same, ranging from works by Vivaldi and Handel to Martin Hennessy's ''Virus S'Amuse'' and Kirk Nurock's ''(Unlikely) Aspirations,'' with collaborators including Heidi Skok, a soprano; Kenneth Hamrick, a harpsichordist, and Mr. Hennessy, a pianist. Sunday at 2 p.m., St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue, at 53rd Street, (212) 316-3321. Tickets: $20; $15 for students and the elderly (Oestreich).

PAUL JACOBS. Students are naturally exuberant when they finally graduate, but this beats all. The day after his graduation from the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia last weekend, this young organist began a series of the complete Bach organ works, unfolding over 14 consecutive evenings. Here he presents the sixth, seventh and eighth programs, all mingling chorale preludes with more formally based works, like the delightful Toccata, Adagio and Fugue in C (BWV 564), which ends the evening tomorrow. Today, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73rd Street, (212) 288-8920, ext. 267. Admission: suggested donation of $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Oestreich).

LOCRIAN CHAMBER PLAYERS. Something for everyone on this program of music from the last decade of the 20th century. Joan LaBarbara sings her own song and Alvin Curran's. Three trumpeters project John Kreckler's ''OTW.'' Emily Wong George performs Frederic Rzewski's ''A Life,'' and Katie Lansdale gives the premiere of David Macdonald's ''Amen'' for solo violin. Tonight at 8, Christ Chapel, Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 870-6784. Tickets: $10, $8 for students and the elderly (Paul Griffiths).

THE MET ORCHESTRA. One of the best ideas James Levine has ever had was to present the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in a series of orchestra concerts. The Met Orchestra, the title the players prefer when they perform in concert, plays twice this weekend. Tonight at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the program will offer Bartok's transfixing one-act opera ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' with the mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter and the bass Samuel Ramey, and works by Debussy, Milhaud and Ravel (''Bolero''). On Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall ''Bluebeard's Castle'' will be repeated, paired this time with Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra. The concerts will be the last performances by the concertmaster Raymond Gniewek, who is retiring after 43 years. Tonight at 8: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Prudential Hall, 1 Center Street, Newark. Tickets are $15 to $64. For more information: (888) 466-5722. Sunday at 3 p.m.: Carnegie Hall. Remaining tickets are $66, $96 and $126. CarnegieCharge: (212) 247-7800 (Tommasini).

NEW YORK CHORAL SOCIETY. The venerable amateur singing group takes over Carnegie Hall to sing Dvorak's lovely choral piece the ''Stabat Mater.'' John Daly Goodwin conducts. The soloists are Eva Urbanova, Jill Grove, Richard Clement and Richard Bernstein. Carnegie Hall, tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $15 to $60, (212) 247-7800 (Bernard Holland).

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Michael Daugherty composes orchestral works with a pop culture sensibility, colorful scoring and ear-catching titles. His latest is ''UFO,'' for percussion and orchestra, and for the work's New York premiere, he has the benefit of both Leonard Slatkin, a conductor who knows his work and is devoted to American music, and Evelyn Glennie, a percussionist whose virtuosity and imagination seems to have no limits. Sharing the program with Mr. Daugherty's work is Stravinsky's Symphony of Wind Instruments and the Schumann ''Rhenish'' Symphony. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. A Young People's Concert, with only Mr. Daugherty's work, will be presented tomorrow at 2 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $18 to $77 for tonight and tomorrow evening; $6 to $21 for the Young People's Concert (Kozinn).

ORION STRING QUARTET. The Orion String Quartet has played all of the 16 Beethoven quartets since its founding in 1987. But its current series of six concerts at Alice Tully Hall is the first time the quartet has played the cycle complete. Each concert honors a New York City organization that does work with children in the arts. There are two concerts this weekend. Tonight's is in honor of the Brooklyn Children's Museum and offers the early Quartet in A major No. 5 (Op. 18) and the late Quartet in A minor (Op. 132). Sunday afternoon's program, in honor of Mind-Builders Creative Arts Center, offers the Quartet in G No. 2 (Op. 18), the ''Harp'' Quartet and the Quartet in B flat (Op. 130). Alice Tully Hall. Tonight at 8 and Sunday at 5 p.m. The concerts are free, but tickets must be picked up before the event at the door. Information: (212) 875-5788 (Tommasini).

ROUND ABOUT. Dawn Upshaw is joined by Gregg Edelman in a new stage performance commissioned by Lincoln Center to cap its three-concert presentation of the singer. Involving songs by Vernon Duke, George Gershwin, Kurt Weill, Stephen Sondheim and others, the production is by Michael Mayer, with music direction by Eric Stern. Tonight at 8:30, John Jay College, 899 10th Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $40, sold out but returns may be available (Griffiths).
Dance

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER. Advance word on Kevin McKenzie's new production of ''Swan Lake'' is that it is a beauty. The New York premiere is tonight. The weekend's casts will be headed by Susan Jaffe and Jose Manuel Carreno (tonight), Ashley Tuttle and Angel Corella (tomorrow afternoon) and Nina Ananiashvili and Julio Bocca (tomorrow night). One bit of intriguing casting has the Russian classicist Vladimir Malakhov dancing the evil wizard von Rothbart tonight. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $75. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 362-6000 (Jennifer Dunning).

FRED BENJAMIN. One of the unsung influences on New York dance today, Fred Benjamin presents four dances with guest artists Marilyn Banks, Christopher Huggins and Charles Malik Lewis. Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $16. Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street; (212) 864-5400 (Dunning).

BEPPIE BLANKERT. This Dutch choreographer's ''Double Track'' pairs dancers with mirrors, and the effect is spectacular. Thanks to illusions involving reflections, people seem to vanish and reappear magically while they wait for a train. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7 and 9; Sunday night at 7, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077. Tickets: $20; $14 for students and the elderly (Jack Anderson).

ANN CARLSON. A choreographer noted for her unusual use of spaces turns the entire Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan into an outdoor stage in her ''Night Light.'' History collides with contemporary life as audiences are taken on a walking tour through the area, pausing in gardens, back alleys, churches and apartments while dancers enact scenes from Chelsea's past. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Reservations and information about meeting points: (212) 255-5793, ext. 11. Tickets: $15 (Anderson).

DANCE RINK. Scott Rink, who has danced with Lar Lubovitch, explores a world drawn from images of post-World War I German painters in ''Of Melodrama and Murder,'' a theater and dance piece set to early Kurt Weill songs performed by Jack Donahue. Tonight and tomorrow night at 10:30. Tickets: $15. Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village, (212) 647-0202 (Dunning)

MIMI GARRARD DANCE THEATER. An early explorer of multimedia dance with an emphasis on lighting and electronic effects, Mimi Garrard celebrates the 35th anniversary of her company with a retrospective that ranges from ''Reflections on an Ecuadoran Jungle'' to ''Joplin Suite.'' Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $8 for students. Theater of the Riverside Church, 120th Street and Claremont Avenue; (212) 674-6868 (Dunning).

TERRY HOLLIS. This workshop production of Terry Hollis's theater and dance piece ''NewSex'' -- hope springs eternal -- is set to music by Sean Meehan. Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12; $8 for students and the elderly; TDF vouchers accepted. Dixon Place at Vineyard 26, 309 East 26th Street, Manhattan; (212) 532-1546 (Dunning),

IRENE HULTMAN. A parody of today's attitudes about love, Irene Hultman's new ''Love, Betrayal and a Bowling Trophy'' draws on theater texts by Moliere, Byron and Shakespeare and uses music that includes opera and Spanish love songs. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30; Sunday night at 7:30. Tickets: $12; TDF vouchers accepted. Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village; (212) 674-8112 (Dunning).

LOUIS JOHNSON DANCE THEATER. ''Malindy,'' a lively and loving look at rock and opera divas drawn from a poem by Paul Dunbar, will be performed with other works by Louis Johnson, the modern-dance and movie musical choreographer and the head of dance at the Henry Street Settlement. Bruce Hawkins will narrate. Other guest artists include Adrienne Armstrong, Sandy Alvarez, Eyn Williams and the singer Roslyn Borroughs. Also on the bill is Louis's Henry Street Kids, a show-stealing group of very young pros. Today and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 5:30 p.m. Tickets: $12; $6 for students and the elderly. Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side; (212) 598-0400 (Dunning).

''JOYCE SOHO PRESENTS.'' Dance by Kathryn Sullivan, Ivy Baldwin, Tina Croll and Charlotte Adams in this third and closing festival weekend. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $10; TDF vouchers accepted. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street; (212) 334-7479 (Dunning).

PEARL LANG DANCE THEATER. Pearl Lang, who joined Martha Graham's company in 1942 and established her own troupe in 1952, celebrates her dancing past and looks to the future in a program of old and new works. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m., Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, (212) 772-4448. Tickets: $24 (Anderson).

MICHAEL MAO DANCE. Michael Mao presents six dances and excerpts from pieces, including ''Weaving,'' set to Kodo drum music, which looks back on Mr. Mao's childhood memories of Southeast Asia. Today, Wednesday and Thursday at 9 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and the elderly. Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, West Village; (212) 595-5851 (Dunning)

MONTE/BROWN DANCE. New and recent dances by Elisa Monte and David Brown, including a dance by Mr. Brown called ''Let's Misbehave'' that is set to music by Cole Porter. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $35. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea; (212) 242-0800 (Dunning).

NEW YORK CITY BALLET. The girl is kissed again -- and again -- in a full weekend of performances of ''The Sleeping Beauty.'' Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 amd 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $72; $10 for student rush tickets. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570 (Dunning).

CYNTHIA OLIVER. In her new ''Shemad'' (separate the syllables), Cynthia Oliver ranges from Caribbean myth to everyday madness. Ms. Oliver, a former dancer with Ronald K. Brown and a Bessie Award-winning choreographer in her own right, will perform with her five-member group to music by Straylight. Tonight through Sunday night at 8:30. Tickets: $15. Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village; (212) 477-5288 (Dunning).

JOHN PASSAFIUME DANCERS. With the aid of puppets, projected photographs and choreographed dream sequences, John Passafiume's ''Visions in the Fun House'' examines the repercussions child abuse has on the survivor and shows how a wounded soul struggles to gain control and trust itself again. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 and 8 p.m., Clark Studio Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 627-8627. Tickets: $22 (Anderson).

CHET WALKER: ''SEDUCTION.'' Chet Walker, who conceived the Broadway musical ''Fosse'' and recreated the choreography of Bob Fosse for it, goes out on his own with ''Seduction,'' a dance and music-theater piece about passion and romance. Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25. Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, Manhattan, (718) 291-1086 (Dunning).
